message:
The air around it feels heavy, pressing on your chest. Whispers you can't quite hear seem to emanate from the mark, tugging at the edges of your mind.
Do you dare to touch it?

The moment your hand meets the mark, an icy jolt shoots through your body. A voice echoes in your mind, low and venomous, yet pleading:
"You...You must help me...End this torment... Seek the one I am bound to... in the place you call Crossglen..."
Your vision blurs, and a suffocating sense of dread wraps around your heart. For a fleeting moment, you glimpse a shadowed figure, writhing in agony, before it vanishes.

You stagger back, your body cold and trembling. Something has changed.

The weight of the mark grows heavier on your mind. A strange, oppressive feeling claws at your chest, urging you to leave this place and return to Crossglen.
You can't shake the feeling that something is terribly wrong there--your father, Mikhail, needs you. You must hurry.

The pull of the mark is becoming harder to ignore. A sudden wave of dizziness washes over you, and the whispers grow louder. They speak of danger, of a life lost if you do not return.
You must turn back... time is running out. Crossglen calls. You cannot linger here.

Your steps grow heavier, the air thick with oppressive energy. The pull within your chest tightens, and the whispers now sound desperate, almost frantic.
Return to Crossglen... You cannot stay here. Your father's life is in peril. Do not test fate any longer!

You feel your breath catch in your throat, the world around you warping and twisting. The mark is burning, a cold fire coursing through your veins, clawing at your very soul.
TURN BACK NOW! Crossglen is in danger. You are too far from what matters. Return at once--before it is too late!
What's gotten into you? I'm fine, but the same can't be said for Leta. I've seen her pacing in that house of hers, muttering to herself like a madwoman. You might want to check on her.
I am most certainly not in the mood to deal with you right now. Why can't Mikhail ever control his kids?

replies.text: Leta, are you all right? Mikhail said you've been acting strange.

message: Strange? Who does he think he is, meddling in my life? I'm fine! Just...leave me alone!

replies.text: You don't seem fine. You've been pacing, muttering to yourself. Something isn't right.

message: Not right? Not right! What would you know about it? You don't know what I've seen, what I've felt!
You want to know? You want to understand? Fine. You'll see...but you won't like what you find.
A dark aura surrounds Leta as a spirit begins its manifestation. Leta lets out a cry and vanishes as the spirit rises.
[taunting] You shouldn't have meddled, little one. This vessel belongs to me now, and so does its anger!
The Dark spirit has been defeated, but you feel as if this issue is unresolved. Something is telling you that it has fled back to the devastated lands south of Stoutford.
Destroy me? Foolish mortal! I am older than your bloodline, stronger than your resolve. You will break, just like the others. Their despair feeds me, and yours will be no different!
The spirit swirls with dark energy, causing the ground to tremble as it prepares to attack.
Let me show you what true suffering feels like. You will know despair, and your name will be forgotten in the darkness of my power!

replies.text: Let me show you the darkness of my power!

message: As the dark spirit fades, the suffocating darkness that had plagued this place begins to lift. The air feels lighter, though the oppressive aura of this devastated land remains, its sinister nature woven into the very ground. Yet, deep within, you feel an uneasy twinge...a faint whisper that the spirit's defeat may not be the end of its influence. Something or someone may still be tied to its lingering power.
I am terrified! Who are those old people upstairs?

replies.text: Seriously? You are scared of your own parents?

message: Those people? No, no, no, they are not my parents. You liar!

replies.text: I'm sorry to say that, but it is true...I think.

message: [Calm, almost welcoming.] Ah, there you are. You've come back to see us, then.

replies.text: Oromir? What happened to you two? You look...different.
Oh, it's still so hard to see you like this. But I still have questions.

message: [Calm, almost welcoming.] Ah, there you are. You've come back to see us, then.

replies.text: Leta? What happened to you two? You look...different.
Oh, it's still so hard to see you like this, so I should leave now.

message: [Thoughtful, but resolute.] Different? Yes, I suppose we are. A weight I didn't even know I carried has been lifted. I feel stronger now, more alive than ever before.
[frail, but smiling warmly] Don't mind him, dear. He's always been dramatic. I may not remember everything, but I know this much--I finally feel at peace.

replies.text: Leta...this isn't normal. You look like you've aged decades overnight. How can you be so calm about this?

message: [with a soft, almost wistful tone] Oh, time catches up to us all, doesn't it? Better to find peace than cling to what's already gone. Whatever you did, thank you. Truly.

replies.text: I didn't do this to you. This doesn't feel right. What happened after the spirit was defeated?

message: Oh, time catches up to us all, doesn't it? Better to find peace than cling to what's already gone. Whatever you did, thank you. Truly.

replies.text: I didn't do this to you. This doesn't feel right. What happened after the spirit was defeated?

message: [Firmly, but not unkindly.] What happened doesn't matter anymore. What matters is that the darkness is gone, and we can finally live. You should do the same. Let it rest. Ease your mind and later, if you still have questions, please visit us then.

While looking between Leta and Oromir, you are unsettled by their calm acceptance. The house feels peaceful, but the air is heavy with unanswered questions.

Leta and Oromir's transformations are undeniable. Their peace is haunting, a reminder that not all wounds leave visible scars. The spirit may be gone, but its mark remains.
[Thoughtful, but somehow annoyed.]
Different? Yes, I suppose we are. Some more than others.
[frail, but confidenty] Don't mind her. She's just not use to me being so assertive.

replies.text: Oromir...this isn't normal. You look like you've aged decades overnight. How can you be so calm about this?

message: So...you've seen them, haven't you? Leta and Oromir?

replies.text: Yeah, I've seen them. They're...old. What happened to them?

message: They weren't like that yesterday. I saw Leta in the fields, tending to her garden, just as spry as ever. Then this morning...well, you've seen it yourself.

replies.text: Did either of them say anything to you? About what happened?

message: [more skeptical, arms crossed] Old's putt'' it lightly. They look ancient, like they lived a hundred winters in just one night.
[shaking his head, grim] Not a word. Just that vacant smile of hers, like everything's fine. Oromir, though...he's got this strange look in his eye. Like he knows something we don't.
[With a gentle smile.] Of course. Ask what you will. We owe you that much.

replies.text: Why were you affected too? Leta was the one possessed by the spirit, not you.
In your basement, I talked to a man, a farmer-looking man that is. I suspect that he is your child. But he is frightened and confused...

message: While sighing, his voice remains steady.

Well, my child, you see, once I entered into the sacred bond of marriage with Leta, I too became bound to the spirit. Our lives, our fates, were entwined by the very vows we spoke. When she was touched by its darkness, I could not help but share in the burden.

replies.text: So, the bond between you two extended even to the curse?

message: Yes. That's the nature of true union, is it not? In love and in struggle, we are as one. Her pain became mine, just as her redemption became ours. The spirit's malice sought to age us, to wear us down. But we endure, thanks to you.

replies.text: Do you regret it? Being tied to her curse?

message: While shaking his head with a warm smile, Oromir continues...

Never. Leta is my heart, my reason for every breath. If carrying this weight was the price of sharing my life with her, then I'd pay it a thousand times over. Love isn't just about the light, it's about standing together, even in the shadows.

replies.text: [pausing] That's admirable. I hope you both find some peace now.

message: We will. Time may have taken its toll, but the darkness is gone. Now, we can live what remains of our days in quiet gratitude. Thank you, truly.
Oromir's voice is somber, yet a slight trember can be heard within it.

replies.text: Tomas? How could this happen to him? He's a grown man now, but he acts as if he's still that frightened child.

message: Our son...Yes, you are right. That is Tomas. Though, to him, he may as well be a stranger to himself.
Oromir sighs deeply while clasping his hands.

replies.text: ...grew older like you both, why does he seem...stuck, mentally?

message: When the spirit latched onto Leta, its curse didn't just affect her. It spread to everything close to her--her home, her family, even our boy. He was only two years old when it began...always holding her hand, always by her side. The spirit saw him as an extension of her, and so it bound him as well.

The spirit didn't just age us. It fed on our memories, our sense of self. Tomas was too young to defend himself from its grasp. It stripped away his connection to who he was. Trapping him in fear and confusion, unable to grow in mind, even as his body aged.

replies.text: Is there any way to help him? He's terrified to leave the basement.

message: Perhaps, with time. The curse is gone, but the scars it left behind are deep. He needs patience, kindness and someone to guide him back to himself. I fear we may not have the strength to do it alone.

replies.text: Yes, he needs time. I hope it works out for you three.

A swamp creature, but far from the kind you'd expect to see. This one is massive, venomous, and ravenous. It's draining the life from my medicinal pools. Strength alone won't save you. You'll need to learn the ways of the swamp.
You've proven resourceful. Perhaps you are worthy of the knowledge I carry. The swamp holds more than muck and mire, and so do the creatures that call it home.

replies.text: You mentioned leeches earlier. What did you mean by that?

message: Leeches are simple creatures, but they hold incredible power. With the right knowledge, they can purge poison, stop bleeding, and heal wounds that no salve can touch. Few have the courage to learn their secrets.
I don't waste my time on fools, but you've proven yourself. Watch closely.
Vaelric produces a jar filled with wriggling leeches and demonstrates their use on a wounded arm.
See how the leech attaches itself? It draws out the bad humors, cleansing the blood. Placement is everything. Here, take this.

replies.text: [Extend my hand and take the leech.]
[Extend my hand and take the leech.]

message: Don't underestimate them. In skilled hands, they are as effective as any blade or potion. Use them wisely.

replies.text: Thank you. Is there anything else I should know?

message: Vaelric hands you a leech.
Yes. Don't waste them on minor cuts or trifling ailments. Save them for when they're truly needed. The swamp still has more to teach you, if you are willing to learn.

Once, I was a celebrated healer. They called me a miracle worker for curing the incurable. My methods were...unconventional. Leeches, parasitic creatures, even plants most would call poisonous. I used whatever the swamp could offer.

Innovation often breeds fear. When a Laumwill noble entrusted me with his life, I used every method I knew to save him. But he died under my care, and the courts called it murder. The Laumwills made certain there was no place for me among civilized men.
It's time to revisit Vaelric.

As you press your hand against the door, the ancient wood groans under the pressure. With a firm push, the entire structure collapses in a loud crack.

The hinges snap free, and the brittle wood shatters as the door comes loose in your grip. You instinctively hurl it to the side, where it hits the ground and crumbles into a pile of splintered wood and dust.
The way forward is now clear, though the remains of the door serve as a testament to its decay.
Your jaw drops in amazement...

I found this bell in the graveyard. [Show Vaelric]
I found this music box in the graveyard. [Show Vaelric]

message: Well that's unfortunate...for you.
Look for anything that might tell us more about who was buried there and why the grave was disturbed.
As you wander around the outskirts of the overgrown graveyard, your eye is drawn to a faint glimmer of metal partially buried beneath the dirt.

Kneeling down, you brush aside the thick grass to uncover what appears to be a small, rusted bell, almost entirely concealed by the earth. You dig carefully with your hands, pulling away stubborn roots and clumps of soil. The bell feels unexpectedly heavy in your grasp, as if it holds more than its physical weight, perhaps a story or purpose yet to be uncovered.
As you near the disturbed burial plot, a faint outline catches your eye, something small and angular sticking out from the soil a few feet away.

Kneeling down, you push aside loose dirt and grass with your fingers. Bit by bit, you uncover a weathered music box, its edges worn smooth by time. Though dirt clings to its surface, you can see delicate carvings etched into the wood. Gently lifting it from the ground, you feel an eerie chill, as if the box has been waiting here, forgotten but not entirely at rest.
Beneath your feet, under a think layer of grass, you notice what looks to be human bones.

You kneel down and brush the blades aside, revealing the unmistakable curve of a bone partially buried in the soil. Carefully clearing away more dirt, you uncover fragments of what appears to be a human skeleton. Judging by its position and proximity to the disturbed grave, it seems likely these remains belong to whoever was once buried here.
Oh, a human? A human, indeed. How surprising. Yes, surprising indeed, but useful. Yes, useful indeed.
A chill runs down your spine as you step back, leaving the bones undisturbed and pondering what might have led to their unearthing.
No, no, no. I ask the questions.
The graveyard west of here, have you been there?
Did you find anything on your way from there to here?
Let me see what you found.

replies.text: Yes, but I didn't keep them.
Yes, but I didn't keep both.
Yes, but I didn't keep both.
Why should I give them to you when I think I need them?

message: Wait! Don't answer that. I can already tell from the expression on your face that you have not found all that I desire.
There are two items that I desire located somewhere between here and the graveyard. Find them and return them to me.

replies.text: Is there anything else I should know?

message: Yes, you need to give me my things or we are not friends.

message: I came to Vaelric in my hour of greatest need, bearing little but a token of my past. A ring of no great value to anyone but myself. I was desperate, suffering, and he agreed to help me for a price. Not gold, not silver, but my ring. I was too weak to refuse, too lost to question his demand.
I have a story to tell only to "friends". So being my "friend" means giving me those two items you found.
There's nothing else of value or interest in this drawer as you've already stolen the ring.

Various trinkets and vials clutter the space, but your eyes are drawn to a small, unassuming pouch tucked toward the back. It feels too light for coins, too solid for herbs. Loosening the drawstrings, you reveal a ring, simple yet striking, just as Eryndor described.

As you slide open the wide drawer, its wooden frame creaks loudly, echoing through the quiet house. You freeze, heart pounding, listening for any sign that Vaelric may have heard from downstairs. After a tense moment of silence, you refocus and scan the contents.
And?

replies.text: I wasn't able to find any clues surrounding the grave site. Is there something you're not telling me?

message: No, just a suspicion I had. In any event, thanks for looking into it for me. Good luck on your search for Andor.
So, you return with my ring?

replies.text: Yes, here it is. [Hand it over]
Yes, here it is. [Take it off and hand it over.]

message: Eryndor's ghost flickers with anticipation as you hold out the ring. His spectral fingers pass through it at first, but he quickly pulls back, composing himself.
You really did it? You took it from him? Hah... good. Maybe now he will understand what it is to have something stolen away.
Vaelric's expression darkens, his fingers tightening around his staff. He turns away for a moment, exhaling slowly before speaking.

replies.text: He says you treated him once, but you buried him alive. That's why he haunts you. He wants his ring back, or the hauntings will continue.
Please tell me more about Eryndor.

message: Eryndor... Yes, I remember. He came to me alone, desperate, barely able to stand. His condition was severe, far beyond anything my tinctures and poultices could mend. I did everything I knew. I bled out the sickness, cooled his fever, forced broth past his lips. But it wasn't enough. One morning, I found him still as death. No breath, no warmth. His skin had gone pale and lifeless.
He rubs his temple, his voice quieter now.

I had no choice but to lay him to rest. There was no kin to claim him, no priest to see to his rites. So I carried him to the graveyard myself, dug the earth with my own hands, and gave him what peace I could. It was the right thing to do... or so I thought.
His jaw tightens, regret flashing in his eyes.

But I was wrong. I was wrong. Somehow, he still lived. I don't know if it was some illness that mimicked death or if I simply failed to see the life still in him. Either way, my hands put him in that grave, and now his suffering is on me.
He hesitates, then steps toward a cabinet, opening a drawer with a sigh.
If his spirit will rest with this ring, take it. If that will end this curse, then let it be done.
So, you return with my ring?

replies.text: Yes, here it is. [Hand it over]
Yes, here it is. [Take it off and hand it over.]
I already gave it to you.
I have it, but I've decided to keep it for myself.
I'm wearing it, and you can't have it.
Yes, but I forgot to bring it with me. I will have to come back later.

message: Eryndor's ghost reaches out, his translucent fingers trembling as they hover over the ring in your hand.
You... you actually found it? After all this time?
His voice is softer now, no longer laced with bitterness. He takes the ring, though it merely passes through his spectral palm. For a long moment, he stares at it, lost in thought.
When I came to that swamp, I still had my bell, my music box, and this. But this ring was the only thing of real worth. The only thing I had left to bargain with when my body failed me.
He exhales a slow, weightless sigh, the glow of his form dimming slightly.
Vaelric took it as payment, believing he had done all he could for me. And I hated him for it. Hated him for leaving me in the dark, for shoveling earth over me when I still had breath in my lungs.
He clenches his fist, as if testing the solidity of his fading presence.
But now... now I see things clearer than I did in life. He was wrong, but not cruel. He truly thought I was beyond saving. And perhaps, in a way, I was.
He lifts his gaze to you, his expression unreadable, yet calm.

I have been bound to this world by resentment, by the belief that my suffering was without meaning. But now, with my ring returned, I feel... lighter. It's time to let go.

[With a final, grateful nod, Eryndor begins to fade, his form unraveling like mist in the wind. A whisper lingers in the air before vanishing entirely.]
He stares at the ring for a long moment, the glow of his form pulsing unevenly.

This was mine. My last possession, my last choice. He had no right to claim it when my body still had breath. And now? Now it is back in the hands it belongs in.

[Turning the ring in his hand, lost in thought.]

But don't think this is over. No... he will still know my presence. He will still feel my breath in the dark. This was never just about the ring. It was about what he did. About what he took from me that I can never get back.
His expression shifts, something unreadable in his flickering gaze. A strange hesitation. He looks away for a moment before turning back to you.
You have done me a service, and for that, I am grateful. But there is something else I need from you. Something unfinished. A debt of my own that I must see repaid.

There was one rival who stood above the rest. A relic hunter like myself, relentless and cunning. Her name is Celdar. We crossed paths often, always chasing the same artifacts, always trying to outmaneuver one another. And when it came to one particular prize, I won. The music box. It was something she sought desperately, something she believed should have been hers. I held onto it, not just for its rarity, but because I had bested her.
You did it? You were able to help me? You have prevented the future hauntings?

replies.text: Yes. Hence my being here with my hand out.

message: Well, let me start by saying that you have done me a great service, and for that, I will offer you something few others could. I am no merchant, but I do have remedies, ones you will not find elsewhere. One in particular may prove invaluable to you: the Insectbane tonic.

This tonic does more than ease a fever or numb the pain of a bite. It eliminates the infection entirely. If you have already fallen victim to the Insect contagion poison, one dose will purge it from your body. But more than that, it grants temporary immunity against reinfection. For a time, no swamp vermin, no festering bite, no tainted sting will take hold of you.

But such a remedy does not come cheaply. If you wish for me to prepare this tonic, you must gather the necessary ingredients yourself. Here is what I require:

Five Duskbloom flowers. These rare blossoms can be found in the deepest parts of the swamp, but the creatures there tend to be attracted to them. Their properties are delicate, so bring them fresh.

Five Mosquito proboscises. Harvested from the swamp mosquitoes. You will find no shortage of these creatures near stagnant waters, but mind their bites.

Ten bottles of swamp water. You will find plenty just outside my home. Surface water won't do. You'll need to reach deep, past the filth floating on top. The best stuff is settled at the bottom. Dark, thick, and rich with what gives the swamp its potency. Fill the bottles with that. Take these empty bottles and fill them yourself.

One sample of Mudfiend goo. A secretion found in the depths of mines and tunnels along the Duleian Road. It is the key component that binds the other ingredients together.

Five Duskbloom flowers. These rare blossoms can be found in the deepest parts of the swamp, but the creatures there tend to be attracted to them. Their properties are delicate, so bring them fresh.

Bring me these, and I shall prepare ten vials of the tonic for you. But understand this: my craft is no charity. If you seek to replenish your supply, you must pay the price. Four hundred and eighty gold per vial. A steep price, perhaps, but a fair one for something that could mean the difference between life and death.
I'll take all of the ingredients and your 4800 gold now and I will mix you up a batch of ten tonics

message: You kneel by the swamp's edge and roll up your sleeve. Surface water will not do. Bracing yourself, you plunge your arm in up to the elbow, feeling the thick, murky liquid seep between your fingers. With a slow, steady motion, you fill each bottle, ensuring they contain the dense, dark water Vaelric requires.
You dare? That ring is mine by right! It was stolen from me in death, just as my life was stolen before its time. I will not suffer another thief to profit from my misery.
Eryndor's spectral form flickers violently, the air around him growing thick with a bitter chill.
You may hold it now, but I promise you, it will not remain in your grasp for long. I will tear it from your fingers, along with the flesh that clings to it!

replies.text: I just hope I don't die for this.

message: As Eryndor's spectral form wavers, his anguished cry echoes through the Galmore encampment before fading into the night. His essence shatters like mist caught in the wind, dissolving into nothing, but the air remains heavy, charged with an unseen weight. The encampment is silent, yet the silence is not one of peace.
So, it is done? You struck him down, ended his torment by force?
I suppose I should have expected as much.
His gaze lingers on you, his expression hard to read. Somewhere between frustration and resignation.
And what of the hauntings? Is it over?
With your hesitation preventing you from getting a word in...
I see. You took the ring for yourself and left his spirit unfulfilled. That was your choice.
He lets out a slow breath, his voice quieter now, laced with disappointment.
Andor would have done better.
[Turning away, he mutters:] I will take what peace I can, while it lasts. But do not expect my gratitude.

He worked his craft, took his payment, and let me rest. But I never awoke under his roof. I awoke beneath the earth, buried like a thing to be discarded. I clawed my way free, but the world had already moved on without me. My body failed, my breath faltered, and I perished alone.

And now, even in death, I remain. I am left with nothing while Vaelric hoards the last piece of my past. That ring was mine, and it was never his to take.
Return my ring, and this torment ends for both of us. Vaelric can go on with his life, and I will trouble him no more. That is my offer.

replies.text: You have been wronged, and I will not let that stand. I will get your ring back, one way or another.
If what you say is true, then this should not be settled with more deceit. I will speak to Vaelric. Maybe there is a way to resolve this fairly.

message: We were in the middle of my story...
Then you see the truth. Vaelric took from me when I had nothing, and now he clings to what is not his. I will be waiting, but not always here in this spot. I will not forget this, friend.

Fair? What was fair about what he did to me? Do you think words will undo my suffering? I have lingered here too long for empty promises. But... if you truly mean to help, then do not return with excuses. Only with my ring.

replies.text: I will come back with answers.

message: Eryndor looks down at the music box, his expression unreadable.
But now? What does a dead man need with a relic? It is time to put an old contest to rest. I want you to find Celdar and give this to her. Not as a gesture of kindness, but because it is right.

replies.text: "Celdar", you say? I think I met her.

message:
Celdar is from Sullengard. If you don't recall speaking with her, that would be the place to start. But I suspect you have met her before. She is not one easily forgotten. She does not tolerate fools, nor those who waste her time with petty sales or empty words. Always clad in that garish purple dress of hers, standing out as if daring the world to challenge her. And she has never taken a loss lightly.

[He holds out the music box, waiting for you to take it.]
Have you brought the music box to Celdar yet?
Thank you!
What are you waiting for? Get going!
I thought you were looking for your brother? What's the matter, you couldn't find Andor, so you gave up and are now looking for someone new?
Now there's a name I haven't heard in a long time. I don't think she's been in town for a long time.
Oh, how can I help you? It's not Mayor Ale is it?

replies.text: What? No. I am looking for Celdar. I've heard she lives here. Is she around by chance?

message: Yes she is a local, but she hasn't been seen around here for a while. Last I heard, she was headed for Brimhaven to do some shopping. Although, it is a long journey so she probably had to rest along the way.

Eryndor? That scoundrel finally got what was coming to him, did he? And now you're here, dangling a prize in front of me, expecting what? Gratitude? Payment? Hah! Whatever trick you think you're playing, I'm not biting.
Celdar pauses, and narrows her eyes as she assesses you.

replies.text: I have this music box. [Showing it to her.]

message: Wait... you're serious, aren't you? He actually sent you to bring me the music box? Hmph. That doesn't sound like him. He was always the type to take, not give.

replies.text: He wanted to do the right thing.

message: The right thing? Eryndor always did have a flair for the dramatic, but this... this is unexpected.
While crossing her arms, she begins to study you.
I spent years chasing that wretched box, only for him to snatch it out from under me. And now, after death, he decides to hand it over? What, am I supposed to be touched?
She scoffs but reaches out for the box.

replies.text: You reach out, your hands meet with the mysterious music box held between your hands and she takes it from you.
I can't believe this, but I forgot to bring the music box. Sorry. I will have to come back later. Stay here.
I just gave you that music box...

message: Hmph. Fine. If he truly meant it, then I'll take it. Not that it changes anything. Eryndor and I were never friends, and his little gesture won't rewrite history. But... at least he finally understood what was mine to begin with.
She examines the box for a moment, running a hand over it before giving you a final look.
Here, take this longsword, I have no need for it. But...
Tell me, does he rest easy now, or is he still out there, clinging to unfinished business?

replies.text: No, he's not at peace. He's still out there, lingering about, bound by unfinished business.

message: Celdar exhales sharply, her fingers tightening around the music box as she looks away for a brief moment.
Hmph. Figures. The stubborn fool never knew when to let go.
She turns the box over in her hands, her expression briefly unreadable. Then, softer, almost to herself:
Chasing relics, chasing victories, chasing debts that can never be repaid... I suppose it doesn't matter now.
She shakes her head, composing herself before glancing at you once more.
Well, he made his choices. And I made mine. But... I wouldn't wish that kind of fate on anyone. Not even him.
With that, she straightens her posture, her usual sharpness returning, though the moment of reflection lingers in her eyes.

replies.text: I hope that in the future, that music box brings your happiness.

message: What are you waiting for? Go get my ring back from Vaelric.
I feel restless here, I was a traveler when I was alive.
Thank you, friend.
He exhales sharply, shaking his head.

The hauntings have ceased. Vaelric will know relief, at least for a time.

And yet, a lingering unease settles in your gut. Something about the way Eryndor vanished, unfinished and unresolved, leaves you with the gnawing certainty that his story is not truly over.
Sticky mud coats your fet and legs, making every motion sluggish and heavy.
As you move your hands up the vine, you begin to hear the vine snapping...
The brittle vines blow off into the wind while you go tumbling to the ground.
As you walk by the table, in the corner of your eye, you catch a glimpse of someone's journal. Do you want to read it?

message:
Day 1
I don't know if I'll ever see Remgard again, but if anyone finds this, know that I tried. I ran the moment I saw a chance, slipping past the guards, through the tunnels, and into the night. I thought the mountain would be my salvation, but it has become another prison. My leg is wounded from a bad fall, and my rations were left behind in my haste. This cabin is the only thing keeping me from dying out in the cold.

I think about you, Elira. About little Matrin and your sweet voice by the fire. I promised I would return, but now I fear I will break that promise. If only I had been stronger. If only I had never been taken to Undertell.

Day 2
I tried again tonight. The moment darkness swallowed the land, I hobbled my way to the river's edge, thinking I could follow the water down the mountain. But they were there - the river wretches. I heard them first, the awful gurgling croaks, the splashing as they slithered from the water. Their eyes glowed like dying embers, watching me, waiting.

I barely made it back inside before one of them lunged. My leg is worse now, and I have nothing left to bind it.

The hunger gnaws at me. I tried fishing, but the hooks in this cabin are rusted, the line too weak. There are old nets, but I do not have the strength to set them.

Tomorrow, I will try again. I have to.

replies.text: This is mildly interesting. Let's read the next page.

message:
Day 3
The cold seeped into my bones last night. It is colder here than in the mines, though there we had fire - if we dug enough, if we obeyed. My hands shake too much to write properly. I tore the floorboards loose, hoping for dry wood, but it does little to warm this place.

I dreamed of the Heartstone. Of its glow deep in the dark, pulsing like a dying heart. We bled for it, all of us. Bent our backs, broke our bodies. They say it fuels the forges of kings, but to us, it was nothing but suffering. I wonder if the others still dig, still rot in the depths of Undertell. Or if they, too, have tried to flee and perished in the dark.

message:
Day 4?
I lost track of time. The hunger dulls everything. My wound festers, and I am too weak to move. I hear the wretches outside every night now, closer than before. As if they can smell my weakness.

I wrote a letter to you, Elira. It's tucked beneath the heartstone. If anyone finds this journal, please... please bring it to Remgard. Let her know I never stopped trying to return.

I will rest now. Perhaps in dreams, I will walk home at last.
